comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:16.0) Gecko/16.0 Firefox/16.0a1
Build ID: 20120619030538

Steps to reproduce:

I use the switching language dropdown selector **at the bottom of the page** in the footer from the page https://developer-new.mozilla.org/fr/docs/CSS/R%C3%A9f%C3%A9rence_CSS to switch to the en-US language 


Actual results:

I was send to https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/new?slug=R%C3%A9f%C3%A9rence_CSS&parent=1312 and asked to create this new page


Expected results:

Ether way (I have no opinion on what should be the right behavior) : I should be send to https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS/CSS_Reference OR I should be send to https://developer-new.mozilla.org/fr/docs/CSS/R%C3%A9f%C3%A9rence_CSS with an English interface

If I use the language dropdown menu at the top left side of the page, I'm send from https://developer-new.mozilla.org/fr/docs/CSS/R%C3%A9f%C3%A9rence_CSS to https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS/CSS_Reference which is the right behavior in that case.
Would have to trickle up the translation relationships to the footer link to make this work. This is pretty messy to implement.
Random question: Why do we have a language picker in the footer if we already have one near the top of the page? Is this to keep with some kind of convention?

(In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #2)
> Why do we have a language picker in the footer if we
> already have one near the top of the page?

The language picker near the top of the page is not always there. It's only present on wiki pages that can be translated. Other pages do not have that language picker.

On the contrary, the language picker in the footer is always here, whatever the page is from the wiki or not.
https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/pull/422

Merge pull request #422 from lmorchard/wiki-footer-lang-switcher-770965

fix bug 770965: Override language switcher in footer with document locales

comments.text:
Add statsd/graphite timers to:

* Overall request/response
* KumaScript calls
* Database calls
* Memcache (hit/miss)
Just making sure you guys know: Jake mentioned that we should be all set to use the Graphite server in PHX1.

The settings for kuma on developer-new look like this:

STATSD_CLIENT = 'django_statsd.clients.normal'
STATSD_HOST = '10.8.74.135'
STATSD_PORT = 8125
STATSD_PREFIX = 'developer'

Stage would look like:
STATSD_CLIENT = 'django_statsd.clients.normal'
STATSD_HOST = '10.8.74.135'
STATSD_PORT = 8125
STATSD_PREFIX = 'developer-stage'

Dev would be:
STATSD_CLIENT = 'django_statsd.clients.normal'
STATSD_HOST = '10.8.74.135'
STATSD_PORT = 8125
STATSD_PREFIX = 'developer-dev'


I don't know how or why you'd specify both the stage and prod roots in the same config (nor why AMO does so... maybe they're pushing the same config to both things and have some logic which chooses the proper one), but if you wanted to it would look like this for stage and prod. For us, we push different config files for dev/stage/prod, so you probably only need to specify the right one for the right environment, I'd think...

'roots': {
        'timers': ['stats.timers.developer-stage', 'stats.timers.developer'],
        'counts': ['stats.developer-stage', 'stats.developer']
}

Commits pushed to master at https://github.com/mozilla/kuma

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/120a3a6a8bd02e6fe777c5752a3fb139000fec60
fix bug 775147 - add statsd calls

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/1ea206e38ee955fc572baaa7b52504871e967892
Merge pull request #437 from groovecoder/statsd-775147

fix bug 775147 - add statsd calls

comments.text:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en/Mozilla/WebIDL_bindings

vs.

https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/WebIDL_bindings

MindTouch encodes the brackets in the "[Creator]" section to generate an ID; to preserve links, kuma should do the same (and look into what other characters MindTouch encodes -- probably the non-URL-safe ones).

Commits pushed to master at https://github.com/mozilla/kuma

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/be10b92234bda15a86f98a893b38fc1dce56e1a9
Bug 776703: encode some additional characters in section IDs.

In addition to non-ASCII, MindTouch encodes non-URL-safe and some
additional characters. This brings us to parity and, based on some
testing with a MindTouch install, encodes everything MindTouch
encodes, with the exception of the two angle-bracket characters; so
far as I can tell, those don't need special handling since they end up
HTML-escaped in both MindTouch and kuma.

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/a6db804cfa6239df6366206e494ca3db204e5e8e
Merge pull request #445 from ubernostrum/section-ids

Bug 776703: encode some additional characters in section IDs.
You guys are amazing. At this pace, the burndown chart tomorrow is going to be a vertical line.

assigned_to.real_name: James Bennett [:ubernostrum]
assigned_to.name: jbennett

comments.text:
The TOC seems to get messed up if there are headings generated using templates. See, for example:

https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/XPCOM_Interface_Reference/nsIMemoryReporter

and

https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/XPCOM_Interface_Reference/nsIMemoryReporter#Memory_reporter_kind_constants

The id used for the link in the TOC is generated when the page is saved. To see this in action add a <h2> to a page, save then edit again there will be an id in the tag.

The current method is does not work as the template <hx> tags are added later so they do not get an id. This causes the TOC generator to fail here https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/blob/master/apps/wiki/content.py#L294 as the code has no method of handling the lack of an id.

The TOC is also broken if h tags on a page contain the same text as the id ends up the same for each one. Mindtouch in this case gave each h a numbered id, so the first will have id="header", the second id="header_2" etc, more importantly these are generated after the templates results have been added to the page.
We need to figure out how to deal with this. Is it possible we could have a KumaScript method we could call that would generate an ID for us and let the system know about it or something?
In the short term, these headings came be created with JS on the client side, if necessary.
*** Bug 773716 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Trying to sort this out, because there's a bit of a chicken and egg problem here. The IDs have to be available for kumascript processing - because IDs are used for section includes & etc. Yet, some IDs are generated from headers by script macros.

(In reply to David Walsh :davidwalsh from comment #3)
> In the short term, these headings came be created with JS on the client
> side, if necessary.

For the very very short term, maybe. These IDs are needed on the server side (ie. from a ?raw=1 query) for kumascript processing.

I think I have a start on a fix here: https://github.com/lmorchard/kuma/commit/7f678a441a9b8f485ce4b5c4d09e435495660ed2 The one weird thing I'm running into is that the h2_gecko_minversion template builds a markup tree something like this:

And then, CKEditor insists on sticking

around the macro. And since
inside

is not valid HTML5 - this, then, gets "cleaned up" by bleach into something like this:

So... long story short, the TOC works fine, and #Unit_type_constants goes to the right spot on the page. But, section editing and includes for this particular section are broken because the
is treated as the section - and it's empty except for the single header

Eh, I'll just PR this code: https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/pull/419

The issues with CKEditor and bleach HTML5 repair might be worth followup bugs though.

Commits pushed to master at https://github.com/mozilla/kuma

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/7f678a441a9b8f485ce4b5c4d09e435495660ed2
bug 769399: Stop generating IDs as part of document save, wait until after kumascript processing

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/103c86ffc7e0fb119c75a59145c0b72cc47250da
Merge pull request #419 from lmorchard/generate-section-ids-after-kumascript-769399

bug 769399: Stop generating IDs as part of document save, wait until after kumascript processing

comments.text:
Running multiple web-heads and memcache caused serious performance issues.

Working here: https://etherpad.mozilla.org/developer-new-is-slow
Do we have additional developments or actions needed here?
There are at present no actions related to this that are waiting on IT (as far as I know). I don't know for sure that the problem is "resolved", however.
*** Bug 770271 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Performance has been consistently good, after the changes in bug 770271#c9. Good enough that today we re-enabled a second web node this morning, and it's *still* been good all day.
I haven't noticed any performance issues lately. I'll update bug with any issues I find
Jake, can we run another stress test on the 3 web-heads and put the results here. If they are comparable or better than the single web-head, let's close this.

I've done quite a bit of stress-testing work on this. One thing I determined is that httperf (my tool of choice for the previous testing) does not play nicely with Zeus caching. The headers are correct (it works), but the statistical output is useless... it counts most of the attempts as failures. Disabling the cache fixes this, and in such a config it sustains approximately 3x the hit rate as a single node being hit directly (no Zeus). httperf is rather old and not in active development, so I'm completely willing to chalk this up as a bug in the tool. I like it because it can be nicely scaled to multiple nodes.

Switching to Siege instead of httperf, and I was able to roughly replicate the same performance level without Zeus caching... and it worked *with* caching as well. The performance in that config is (as one would expect) much higher. I suspect it would be higher still, but I reached the limit of what I could feasibly output with a single siege client node. Siege has no convenient way to use several client machines at once, so this is the best I can do without a lot more effort.

Testing against https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/learn:

1 node, directly: 200-250 hits/sec
3 nodes, through Zeus w/ no cache: 720 hits/sec
3 nodes, through Zeus w/ cache: ~4200 hits/sec  <-- client-side testing limitation

This is a pretty synthetic test though- that page was previously chosen because it has minimal MySQL calls and no Kumascript calls... it's about as simple as a Kuma page will ever be.

We could do another test against a more common page, but I'm not sure it's really necessary.


Adding a blocker for getting Graphite to work. I thought that would "just work", but it appears not to.

Things seem snappy. Going to close this and call it done. 

We're still futzing around with statsd, but specific follow-up bugs should be opened from here out. This one seems too general for action items. (ie. "Make it go, make it go fast.")
Agreed. Thanks, Les.

assigned_to.real_name: Nobody; OK to take it and work on it
assigned_to.name: nobody

comments.text:
We've been focused on the new wiki on developer-new. But, meanwhile, two things have been still happening on developer.mozilla.org since we made a snapshot of the site data:

1) New user signups
2) Demo Studio activity (eg. submissions, comments, likes, launches)

So, before we can throw the switch to developer-new, we need to:

1) Compare user rosters on developer and developer-new, copy over any missing user profiles to developer-new

2) Copy over Demo Studio data, taking care to match up the right user profiles in submissions, comments, etc.

I don't think a straight-up mysqldump of the data will work, because of different user rosters and primary key desync. Any ideas? (eg. natural keys? django dump/load data?)

For a sense of the discrepancy:

* 326 demos on developer-new; 383 demos on developer
* 26498 users on developer-new; 22294 users on developer

And that doesn't count comments, likes, launches, tags, etc.

The difference in users seems surprising... how did we get that many more users on developer-new?

> * 26498 users on developer-new; 22294 users on developer

We have been promoting the heck out of it, so it's possible people found it that way. Are we sure all of these new accounts are legitimate?

We could probably live without having the Demo Studio content on developer-new for the soft launch -- I can't imagine that many people will be interested in browsing it there (at least not intentionally).

What about users? When a user hits the "Edit" button on developer, will they need to log in again on developer-new? If they do, we will want to be sure to at least move those accounts over.
Does the migration script already take care of migrating users?

(In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #4)
> Does the migration script already take care of migrating users?

Only users involved in creating wiki pages. It's only a wiki migration script.

(In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #3)

> What about users? When a user hits the "Edit" button on developer, will they
> need to log in again on developer-new? If they do, we will want to be sure
> to at least move those accounts over.

Yes, they will have to log in again. And, if they have signed up on developer.mozilla.org since (I think) around late May, they'll be asked to sign up again until/unless user rosters are merged

(In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #2)
> > * 26498 users on developer-new; 22294 users on developer
> 
> We have been promoting the heck out of it, so it's possible people found it
> that way. Are we sure all of these new accounts are legitimate?

No idea about legitimacy, I just looked at the raw totals. By what criteria would we decide whether or not they're legitimate?

(In reply to Les Orchard [:lorchard] from comment #5)
> (In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #4)
> > Does the migration script already take care of migrating users?
> 
> Only users involved in creating wiki pages. It's only a wiki migration
> script.

Oh, and in particular, it only has migrated users who *contributed* to a wiki page.

(In reply to Les Orchard [:lorchard] from comment #7)
> (In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #2)
> > > * 26498 users on developer-new; 22294 users on developer
> > 
> > We have been promoting the heck out of it, so it's possible people found it
> > that way. Are we sure all of these new accounts are legitimate?
> 
> No idea about legitimacy, I just looked at the raw totals. By what criteria
> would we decide whether or not they're legitimate?

Not sure exactly. Just trying to make sense of the high number.

(In reply to Les Orchard [:lorchard] from comment #8)
> (In reply to Les Orchard [:lorchard] from comment #5)
> > (In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #4)
> > > Does the migration script already take care of migrating users?
> > 
> > Only users involved in creating wiki pages. It's only a wiki migration
> > script.
> 
> Oh, and in particular, it only has migrated users who *contributed* to a
> wiki page.

Can we use that same logic to migrate other types of users? How about new demos?

(In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #10)

> Can we use that same logic to migrate other types of users? How about new
> demos?

If by "use", you mean as inspiration for a new migration command, then sure. But if you mean reuse in terms of code, probably not so much.

I'll take a crack at a migration command to migrate from the old db to new db.

FWIW, developer.mozilla.org only has django users for users who have signed in the last year. developer-new.mozilla.org may have also created older users who show up in wiki documents' history but haven't signed in recently.

(In reply to Luke Crouch [:groovecoder] from comment #12)
> FWIW, developer.mozilla.org only has django users for users who have signed
> in the last year.

Are the rest managed through DekiWiki? Have we looked into migrating those users yet?

The rest are largely inactive users we're leaving behind on DekiWiki - most of them are garbage/spam accounts anyway.

We migrate users as they log in, and we migrate all users who have contributed to a doc on the wiki. We have missed some, which is bug 768524.
Opening up a separate bug for migrating users. See bug 774472.
*** Bug 774472 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I recently deleted a developer.mozilla.org Demo Studio. Will we need to manually delete it on developer-new as well, or will the migration take care of that?
s/deleted a/deleted a demo that was on the

comments.text:
It appears that any response from developer-new.mozilla.org comes with these headers, whether you're logged in or not:
> Pragma: no-cache
> Cache-Control: no-cache, must-revalidate
> Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT

This disables bfcache <https://developer.mozilla.org/En/Using_Firefox_1.5_caching> and makes the pages slower to load.

The production site developer.mozilla.org has its own problems (bug 711371, bug 606190), but at least it doesn't send these headers and not for all requests.


Full headers below.

Request headers:

GET /en-US/docs/DOM/DOM_event_reference HTTP/1.1
Host: developer-new.mozilla.org
Connection: keep-alive
Cache-Control: max-age=0
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_7_4) AppleWebKit/536.11 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/20.0.1132.21 Safari/536.11
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate,sdch
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.8
Accept-Charset: ISO-8859-1,utf-8;q=0.7,*;q=0.3
Cookie: csrftoken=5f7f7a3024aae8cb13788e8adbf16b87; WT_FPC=id=91.79.103.251-3633354272.30229543:lv=1338973424773:ss=1338973424773

Response Headers

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Wed, 06 Jun 2012 21:03:51 GMT
Server: Apache
X-Kumascript-Caching: 200 OK, Age: 0
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Vary: Cookie
x-kuma-revision: 6301
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache, must-revalidate
x-frame-options: DENY
Set-Cookie: csrftoken=5f7f7a3024aae8cb13788e8adbf16b87; Max-Age=31449600; Path=/
X-Backend-Server: developer3.webapp.scl3.mozilla.com
Last-Modified: Tue, 29 May 2012 12:20:28 GMT
Content-Length: 51821
Keep-Alive: timeout=5, max=1000
Connection: Keep-Alive
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8

Did a little digging. This comes from sumo.middleware.NoCacheHttpsMiddleware and is very easily disabled by removing the middleware from settings.py.

Kitsune disabled caching under https:// to address bug 584931. It seems like the main thing there was that personalized info (eg. logged in username) was being cached. But, we send a `Vary: Cookie` header, which should prevent that by requiring a logged in user's cookie to be considered in caching. So, it seems safe to turn this off for us.

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/pull/344

This may help internally, too- Kumascript queries go through Zeus, and Zeus will cache things according to cache headers. So, if we do implement this and it affects the pages Kumascript calls, we'll be alleviating potentially a lot of back-and forth Kuma/Kumascript traffic and turning it into a simple cache hit.

Django->Kumascript I believe does not go through Zeus (or any caching layer), so I don't think there's anything to gain by having cache headers there. Still, short-circuiting some Kumascript->Django traffic seems like a major win.

The Zeus cache has a TTL cap on it... usually 10 minutes. Just mentioning for completeness.

This has a pull request, just pending a review and merge by someone not-me:

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/pull/344

Commits pushed to master at https://github.com/mozilla/kuma

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/9e40c18c0abe3f0a39a77458d77c0c1eb8b93e42
bug 762252: Disable NoCacheHttpsMiddleware to allow caching under HTTPS

https://github.com/mozilla/kuma/commit/18dad6c08fcb297035c065241790855e3a08785a
Merge pull request #344 from lmorchard/disable-nocache-middleware-762252

bug 762252: Disable NoCacheHttpsMiddleware to allow caching under HTTPS

changes.removed: Research: Decide whether to use or avoid Zeus.
changes.added: Research: Decide whether to use or avoid Zeus between Kuma and Kumascript

comments.text:
In the July 18 planning meeting, we discussed that we will need to make a decision on the following:

* Avoid frontend Zeus: Send KumaScript requests to Kuma straight to a  local hostname
* Avoid frontend Zeus: Send KumaScript requests to Kuma straight to a  local hostname
* Add RabbitMQ/celeryd for deferred rendering.

We need to decide this before Tuesday, so please discuss below as soon as possible.

Accidentally copied the first option twice. The correct list should be...

* Avoid frontend Zeus: Send KumaScript requests to Kuma straight to a  local hostname
* Leverage frontend Zeus: Verify Kuma sends proper caching headers for ?raw=1 requests
* Add RabbitMQ/celeryd for deferred rendering.
Not sure if there was a recent change to our Zeus config (ie. a week or so ago), but this might be affecting bug 775132. Still investigating though

FWIW, I don't think devs can make this decision or make the changes to implement it. I think this is an IT thing.

It might help solve bug 775132 to take Zeus out of the Kuma <-> KumaScript loop, but that's not something I can do

Tweaking the title: We have to use Zeus between Kuma and the web. We might be able to tweak things between Kuma and Kumascript.

Also, per the "leverage" option, this is a summary of caching headers sent around between Kuma and KumaScript:

* Kuma and KumaScript use Last-Modified and If-Modified-Since headers to trigger conditional GET and 304 Not Modified responses

* Kuma sends a Cache-Control: no-cache header to Kumascript when a logged-in user hits shift-reload. When that happens, Kumascript in turn sends Cache-Control: no-cache to Kuma when requesting ?raw=1 URLs to get templates and document source to process

* If-Modified-Since headers are not sent from KumaScript when Cache-Control: no-cache is in effect

We don't currently use Expires headers on either side.

At present I'm not aware of any ongoing performance issues, so I'm content to leave this as-is for now.

As a future architectural improvement, I would recommend that we spin up new dedicated Kumascript nodes, behind an internal Zeus VIP. This would give nice pooled connections in both directions (Kuma->Kumascript and Kumascript->Kuma), avoiding a potential situation where Kumascript is overloaded on one particular node (because Kuma->Kumascript currently uses 127.0.0.1). This decouples the two pieces and makes them more independent.

As for caching, this would also give us a Zeus caching layer between Kuma->Kumascript, which may help in some scenarios.


I don't think we should block launch for this change though. It'd just be the next logical evolution of the cluster.

Since I figured out what the problem was with bug 775132, I can stop falsely maligning Zeus. And, for this bug, I'd recommend that we just leave it alone now that kumascript is doing the right thing with caching headers.

It would be nice to have a RabbitMQ/Celery rig for the site, but that's bug 766627

assigned_to.real_name: Nobody; OK to take it and work on it
assigned_to.name: nobody

comments.text:
When trying to update https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS/Getting_Started/JavaScript

I get the error message +Another document with this slug already exists+.

But I didn't touch the slug, and the document already exists (so I can't fix the template error on it.
Same here: https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/SVG/Tutorial/Introduction (I list them here so that I don't forget about them)

Interesting. It looks like the slug does not take the full path into consideration -- docs/CSS/Getting_Started/JavaScript is treated the same as /docs/JavaScript.

In both of these cases, there is an article with the same name but at a different path.

https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/JavaScript
https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Introduction
Yeah, this is happening to me in a couple of places too.
*** Bug 775929 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Here's another:

https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS/length

gives an error, possibly because of...

https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/length
Ali: This bug is not related to reading, but it is one of the more significant editor-facing bugs. Thoughts on blocker status?
Louis-Remi just ran into this in bug 776018. It's affecting a large percentage of the docs team, so it will probably affect a large percentage of our users as well.
Yeah, this is happening on several articles. I have yet to see a pattern.

Sheppy: As far as I can tell, the pattern is this: You cannot save any page that has the same slug as another document.

For example, these two articles have different paths but the same slug. This causes an error.

https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS/length
https://developer-new.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/length

Hm. I was under the impression that the slug is supposed to be the full path of the page other than the part prior to "docs". So the first of those would be "CSS/length" and the second "length". If that's not the case, that's a bug of pretty epic proportions, since we've known all along (and made it quite clear in multiple meetings) that pages with the same name and slug were going to be common due to the same names being used in multiple APIs.

I think I know what the issue could be here, and it's to do with the secondary form validation I created, the one that ensured that no slash was present in slug returned by the form.  

The last piece of the slug gets removed, then validated, so "CSS/length" becomes just "length" which colides with "/length" which is already present.

Sheppy:  This isn't a requirements issue, it's a "there's so much that could happen with slugs that something popped up" issue;  it all relates to only accepting the last piece of the slug heirarchy in the form.  

I'll look to fix during the conference tomorrow.  I'm too exhausted from 3 weeks without a day off to try to fix it tonight.
OK, I've confirmed the root issue, have a solution working locally, will have hopefully by end of day.
*** Bug 776449 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

fix bug 774184 - prevent duplicate slug error message

Right now we push "as-needed" We plan to push today.

Cool thanks.

comments.text:
It seems that the template is being cached. If you change the parameters passed it will produce the correct output for the old version of the template.

After several minutes a force refresh will pick up the changes.

Thanks as always, Trevor.

Les: Is this a dupe of bug 771236?

(In reply to John Karahalis [:openjck] from comment #1)
> Thanks as always, Trevor.
> 
> Les: Is this a dupe of bug 771236?

No I don't think so, that bug is about the editor, this is about rendering pages. separate systems

Investigating this. Here's what I've tried so far this morning, no ideas yet:

* No luck reproducing on laptop VM, or on mdn.lmorchard.com

* Can reproduce on developer-new.mozilla.org

* Editing a template and fetching its ?raw source works as expected - ie. the content is updated after an edit

* Creating a new template and adding a macro to call it in a document results in changes to the page. It's just editing existing templates that come sup with stale content. That feels like caching.

* Doesn't seem like memcache: I edited a template; shift-reload on test page did nothing; flushed memcache on developer{1,2}; shift-reload still did nothing

* Watching the kumascript logs on both developer{1,2} shows that shift-reload does indeed trigger a kumascript request.

Next step is probably to add some more log output to kumascript, especially around cache hits/misses and see what that says.

(In reply to Les Orchard [:lorchard] from comment #3)

> * Editing a template and fetching its ?raw source works as expected - ie.
> the content is updated after an edit

Actually, I take this back. I just saw a curl fetch of ?raw template source come back stale on developer1 from the command line. Maybe a lead, thinking Zeus + caching headers might be involved.
